docs.lead_paragraph: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

docs.lead_paragraph: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

headline.main: How the World Balances Health Care Risk

docs.abstract: A number of countries offer citizens a wide choice of health insurers -- none government-run -- while still excluding age as a criterion in premiums, an economist writes.

docs.lead_paragraph: New Jersey’s Senate has defeated a bill to legalize gay marriage, leaving it unlikely the state will have a gay marriage law in the very near future.

headline.seo: New Jersey Senate Defeats Same-Sex Marriage Bill, 20 to 14
headline.main: New Jersey Senate Defeats Gay Marriage Bill
headline.print_headline: New Jersey Senate Defeats Same-Sex Marriage Bill

docs.snippet: New Jersey’s Senate has defeated a bill to legalize gay marriage, leaving it unlikely the state will have a gay marriage law in the very near future.

keywords.value: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: The State Senate on Thursday rejected a proposal that would have made New Jersey the sixth state in the nation to allow marriages involving same-sex couples. The vote was the latest in a succession of setbacks for advocates of gay marriage across the country. After months of intense lobbying and hours of emotional debate, lawmakers voted 20 to 14 against the bill, bringing tears from some advocates who packed the Senate chambers and rousing applause from opponents of the measure, who also came out in force. The vote ends the effort to win legislative approval of the measure, and sets the stage for a new battle before the New Jersey Supreme Court.

headline.main: New Jersey Senate Defeats Same-Sex Marriage Bill

docs.snippet: New Jersey’s Senate has defeated a bill to legalize gay marriage, leaving it unlikely the state will have a gay marriage law in the very near future.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama has apparently embraced the so-called Cadillac tax, an excise tax on high-priced health insurance plans, urging its inclusion in the final health care legislation to be hammered out between Democratic leaders in the House and Senate. But that Cadillac may be carrying some surprises.
docs.abstract: Pres Obama seems to endorse so-called Cadillac tax, excise tax on high-priced health insurance plans, urging its inclusion in final health care legislation to be hammered out between Democratic leaders in House and Senate; although tax would be levied on employer or health plan administrator, experts agree that it will be passed along to employees (M)
